name: Sony FX3A
notablePros: Real-time Eye AF with subject tracking across the full frame | Clean usable footage up to ISO 51200+, dual base ISO | Compact 640g cinema body with 1/4"-20 and ARRI-standard mounting points
notableCons: Maximum 4K resolution, no 6K or 8K oversampling | Requires CFexpress Type A cards for top recording modes | No built-in ND filters

name: Sony FX6
notablePros: Built-in electronic variable ND filter (2-7 stops) | Dual Base ISO (800/12800) for flexible exposure in mixed lighting | Full-size XLR audio inputs with phantom power on detachable handle
notableCons: No optical IBIS, electronic stabilization only | Similar image quality to FX3 at a higher price | 890g body may need shoulder rig for extended handheld use

name: Sony FX30
notablePros: Cinema-style body with S-Cinetone, S-Log3, and 10-bit 4:2:2 at $1,798 | Same Real-time AF system as the FX3 and A7S III | S-Cinetone color profile produces broadcast-ready color with minimal grading
notableCons: APS-C sensor has a 1.5x crop factor, narrowing field of view | No built-in ND filters | CFexpress Type A cards required for highest-quality recording modes

name: Sony A7S III
notablePros: Excellent low-light performance with clean output up to ISO 51200+ | 9.44M-dot OLED EVF for precise focus and exposure evaluation | Standard mirrorless form factor supports both photo and video workflows
notableCons: Released 2020. The FX3 offers similar image quality in a cinema body | 12.1MP limits print and crop flexibility for stills | No built-in ND filters

name: Sony A7C II
notablePros: 514g full-frame body, one of the lightest in its class | 33MP sensor with 4K60 10-bit and S-Log3 in a compact form factor | AI-based Real-time Recognition AF tracks humans, animals, birds, insects, cars, and trains
notableCons: No 4K120. Maximum is 4K60 | Single SD card slot, no backup recording | Small grip can feel cramped with lenses over 300g

name: Sony A7 IV
notablePros: 33MP sensor performs well for both stills and 4K video | Dual card slots (CFexpress Type A + SD) for redundant recording | 10-bit 4:2:2 S-Log3 provides wide dynamic range for color grading
notableCons: 4K60 applies a 1.5x crop | AF system is a generation behind the A7C II and A7R V | Rolling shutter can be visible with fast panning

name: Sony ZV-E10 II
notablePros: S-Cinetone, 4K60 10-bit, and AI-based AF for under $1,000 | 377g body, compact enough for one-handed vlogging | Same AF engine as Sony's flagship cameras at a fraction of the price
notableCons: No in-body stabilization. Requires a gimbal or optically stabilized lens | NP-FW50 battery rated for about 95 minutes of continuous recording | Single SD card slot, no electronic viewfinder

name: Sony A6700
notablePros: 4K120 recording in an APS-C body at $1,398 | 5-axis IBIS combined with Real-time tracking AF for stabilized handheld shooting | NP-FZ100 battery provides roughly 2x the runtime of the ZV-E10 II
notableCons: Single SD card slot, no redundant recording | 1.5x APS-C crop factor reduces effective field of view on wide lenses | Notable rolling shutter artifacts in 4K120 mode

name: Canon EOS R5 Mark II
notablePros: Internal Cinema RAW Light recording at up to 8K30 | 45MP stacked CMOS sensor for high-resolution stills with minimal rolling shutter | Canon Log 3 with wide dynamic range and well-regarded skin tone rendering
notableCons: Thermal throttling possible in 8K and extended 4K120 recording | Canon RF lenses tend to be more expensive than Sony E or Nikon Z equivalents | Some rolling shutter visible in non-oversampled modes

name: Canon EOS R5 C
notablePros: Internal 8K60 Cinema RAW Light recording | Active cooling fan enables unlimited continuous recording | Separate cinema and photo modes with independent settings
notableCons: No in-body stabilization. Requires a gimbal or rig for handheld work | Cooling fan noise is audible and can be picked up by on-camera microphones | The R5 Mark II covers most of the same specs in a more versatile body

name: Canon EOS R6 Mark III
notablePros: Internal 7K60 Cinema RAW Light recording with 4K120 capability | Canon Log 3 with approximately 14 stops of dynamic range | 32.5MP full-frame sensor with good high-ISO performance up to ISO 25600+
notableCons: Canon RF mount has limited third-party autofocus lens options | No built-in ND filters | Higher price point than the R6 Mark II it replaces

name: Canon EOS R7
notablePros: Effective IBIS combined with Dual Pixel CMOS AF II for action and documentary | 32.5MP APS-C sensor produces detailed stills alongside 4K video | Entry point into Canon RF ecosystem at $1,499
notableCons: Visible noise above ISO 3200 due to APS-C sensor size | 4K60 applies an additional crop beyond the standard 1.6x | Limited selection of native APS-C RF-S lenses

name: Canon EOS R8
notablePros: Full-frame 24.2MP sensor with Canon Dual Pixel CMOS AF II for under $1,500 | 461g body, one of the lightest full-frame cameras available | Canon Log 3 and 10-bit 4:2:2 internal recording
notableCons: No in-body image stabilization | Single SD card slot | 4K60 applies a significant 1.6x crop

name: Canon EOS R50
notablePros: Most affordable Canon RF-mount camera at $679 | 375g compact body with guided menus for new users | 4K30 and Dual Pixel CMOS AF at an entry-level price
notableCons: 8-bit 4:2:0 only, minimal latitude for color grading | No IBIS and no log color profile | LP-E17 battery provides limited recording time, about 50 min continuous

name: Canon EOS C70
notablePros: Built-in ND filters with 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 stop positions | Dual Gain Output (DGO) sensor provides 16+ stops of dynamic range | Compact cinema body at 1,170g with Dual Pixel CMOS AF II
notableCons: Super 35 sensor only, no full-frame option | Cinema RAW Light added via firmware but limited to lower resolutions | SD card slots only, no CFexpress

name: Canon EOS C80
notablePros: Full-frame Cinema RAW Light internal recording at up to 6K | Built-in ND filters and IBIS in a dedicated cinema body | 6K oversampled 4K with Canon Log 3 color science
notableCons: Mini XLR audio inputs only, no full-size XLR | RAW files are very large (requires fast, high-capacity media) | $500 more than the C70 which may suffice for Super 35 workflows

name: Panasonic Lumix S5 IIX
notablePros: Internal Apple ProRes recording, uncommon at this price | Dual native ISO at 640/4000 for flexible exposure in mixed lighting | 6K open-gate recording for reframing flexibility in post
notableCons: Phase-detect AF is less reliable than Sony or Canon equivalents | L-mount lens selection is smaller than E or RF mount | SD card slots only, no CFexpress

name: Panasonic Lumix S5 II
notablePros: Full-frame sensor with phase-detect AF for under $2,000 | Dual native ISO (640/4000) with V-Log for wide dynamic range grading | Effective 5-axis IBIS rated for up to 6.5 stops of compensation
notableCons: No 4K120 recording | No internal ProRes recording (available on S5 IIX) | AF can hunt in low-contrast or backlit situations

name: Panasonic Lumix GH7
notablePros: Internal Apple ProRes and ProRes RAW recording at $2,199 | 4K120 with 5-axis IBIS for stabilized slow-motion handheld shots | CFexpress Type B card slot for high-bitrate recording
notableCons: Micro Four Thirds sensor has limited low-light performance and shallower depth of field | 2x crop factor significantly narrows field of view | 805g, heavy for a Micro Four Thirds body

name: Panasonic Lumix GH6
notablePros: 5.7K60 and 4K120 recording at $1,499 | Internal ProRes and ProRes HQ recording | Active cooling enables unlimited continuous recording
notableCons: Contrast-detect AF only, no phase detection | Micro Four Thirds sensor with 2x crop and limited high-ISO performance | The newer GH7 adds phase-detect AF for $700 more

name: Panasonic Lumix G9 II
notablePros: Phase-detect AF in a Micro Four Thirds body | 5-axis IBIS with Dual I.S. 2 support for up to 8 stops of compensation | 100fps burst shooting with 25MP resolution for action photography
notableCons: No internal ProRes recording | MFT sensor limits high-ISO performance compared to APS-C and full frame | SD card slots only

name: Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera 4K
notablePros: Internal 12-bit Blackmagic RAW recording at $1,295 | 5-inch 1080p touchscreen with on-screen tools (focus peaking, false color, waveforms) | DaVinci Resolve Studio license included ($295 value)
notableCons: No autofocus, manual focus only | LP-E6 battery lasts approximately 45-60 minutes of continuous recording | No in-body stabilization

name: Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera 6K G2
notablePros: Internal 6K Blackmagic RAW recording for under $2,000 | Canon EF mount provides access to decades of cinema and photo lenses | 13 stops of measured dynamic range
notableCons: Canon EF mount with no electronic autofocus support, manual focus only | LP-E6 battery provides approximately 45-60 minutes of recording | No in-body stabilization or autofocus system

name: Blackmagic Cinema Camera 6K
notablePros: Full-frame 6K Blackmagic RAW internal recording at $2,595 | First Blackmagic camera with phase-detect autofocus | L-mount provides access to Sigma, Panasonic, and Leica lenses
notableCons: AF is functional but significantly less reliable than Sony or Canon systems | No in-body image stabilization | NP-F570 battery provides limited recording time

name: Blackmagic PYXIS 6K
notablePros: Full-size XLR audio inputs with phantom power | Box-style body designed for rigging, studio, and multi-camera setups | Same full-frame 6K Blackmagic RAW as the Cinema Camera 6K
notableCons: No built-in screen. Requires an external monitor | Not practical for handheld or run-and-gun shooting | Same basic AF limitations as other Blackmagic cameras

name: Fujifilm X-H2S
notablePros: Internal Apple ProRes recording with 4K120 capability | 19 built-in Film Simulation modes including Eterna for cinema work | Stacked BSI CMOS sensor provides fast readout with minimal rolling shutter
notableCons: APS-C sensor has higher noise at high ISO compared to full-frame cameras | Fujifilm X-mount has fewer cinema-oriented lens options than Sony E or Canon RF | Thermal throttling possible during extended high-frame-rate recording

name: Fujifilm X-H2
notablePros: Internal 8K30 recording from a 40.2MP APS-C sensor | 40.2MP stills with Fujifilm Film Simulation color profiles | Internal Apple ProRes recording
notableCons: No 4K120 recording | 40.2MP on APS-C produces visible noise above ISO 3200 | 8K files require fast storage and a powerful editing system

name: Fujifilm X-T5
notablePros: Dedicated shutter speed and ISO dials with a classic rangefinder body design | 40.2MP sensor with 19 Film Simulation modes for distinctive color rendering | 6.2K30 and 4K60 10-bit internal recording
notableCons: Three-way tilt screen does not flip out for front-facing vlogging | No internal ProRes recording | Designed primarily for photography. Video features are secondary

name: Fujifilm X-S20
notablePros: 6.2K30 and 4K60 10-bit recording at $1,299 | 19 Film Simulation modes built in, including Eterna and Classic Neg | 491g body with 5-axis IBIS providing up to 7 stops of compensation
notableCons: Single SD card slot, no backup recording | No internal ProRes recording | Limited first-party content creator accessories compared to Sony ZV line

name: Nikon Z6 III
notablePros: Internal N-RAW recording with 4K120 capability at $2,499 | Partially stacked CMOS sensor provides fast readout with minimal rolling shutter | Nikon's improved 3D tracking AF with subject detection for people, animals, and vehicles
notableCons: Nikon Z lens ecosystem has fewer third-party options than Sony E mount | Requires proprietary microSD-form CFexpress cards | N-Log color workflow is less widely supported in post-production software

name: Nikon Z8
notablePros: Internal 8K N-RAW recording with the same stacked sensor as the Z9 | 45.7MP stacked CMOS sensor with fast readout and no blackout during burst shooting | Subject-detection AF tracking for people, animals, and vehicles
notableCons: Tilt-only screen, no vari-angle for front-facing recording | 45.7MP generates large files and may be more resolution than needed for 4K delivery | Thermal throttling possible during extended 8K recording sessions

name: Nikon Z50 II
notablePros: 4K60 with N-Log recording in a Nikon Z body for $1,099 | Improved hybrid AF system with subject detection | Compact 550g body suitable for travel and vlogging
notableCons: No in-body image stabilization | Limited native DX (APS-C) Nikon Z lens selection | Single SD card slot

name: DJI Osmo Pocket 3
notablePros: Built-in 3-axis mechanical gimbal stabilization in a 179g pocket-sized body | 1-inch CMOS sensor, larger than most action cameras and smartphones | 4K120 and 10-bit D-Log M recording
notableCons: Fixed 20mm equivalent lens, no interchangeable optics | 1-inch sensor cannot match APS-C or full-frame depth of field and low-light performance | Gimbal mechanism is delicate and can be damaged by impacts

name: GoPro HERO13 Black
notablePros: HyperSmooth 6.0 electronic stabilization with horizon lock up to 360 degrees | Waterproof to 33ft (10m) without a housing | Magnetic latch mounting system for quick attachment and removal
notableCons: 1/1.9-inch sensor produces visible noise in low light | Heavy H.265 compression can limit grading flexibility | Battery life is approximately 60-80 minutes of continuous 4K recording

name: RED KOMODO 6K
notablePros: 16-bit REDCODE RAW recording, the same codec used on major film productions | Canon RF mount provides access to both cinema and photo lenses | Relatively compact cinema body at 1,010g for a RED camera
notableCons: $5,995 is body only. A production-ready rig typically costs $10,000+ | No built-in monitor, audio inputs, or autofocus | REDCODE RAW files require a high-performance editing workstation
